messages.content: ComfyUI-SAL-VTON is based on the paper 'Linking Garment with Person via Semantically Associated Landmarks for Virtual Try-On' published in CVPR2023.

To install ComfyUI-SAL-VTON, clone the repository into the 'custom_nodes' folder, navigate to the folder and run 'pip install -r requirements.txt', download the landmark, warp, and salvton models from the provided links, and create a 'salvton' folder in the ComfyUI 'models' directory to store these models.
What size should the garment image be for ComfyUI-SAL-VTON?
The garment image should be 768x1024 pixels. If the image is not of this size, you can resize it within ComfyUI.
What can affect the quality of the virtual try-on results?
The background of the 'person' image should be white for good results. If the background is not white, consider using rembg or SAM to mask and replace it with a white background.
How do I generate a garment mask?
The garment mask is the shape of the input garment. You can generate it using SAM or rembg, which was used in the provided workflow.
What is the source of the inference code for ComfyUI-SAL-VTON?
The inference code for ComfyUI-SAL-VTON is available on [ModelScope](https://github.com/modelscope/modelscope). The implementation is a simple wrapper around this code.
Who should be acknowledged for the development of ComfyUI-SAL-VTON?

Keyu Y., Tingwei G., and the original authors of the paper 'Linking Garment with Person via Semantically Associated Landmarks for Virtual Try-On' published in CVPR2023, and the authors of the inference code on ModelScope should be acknowledged for their work.
